title: How are some older people heavily dependent on technology now despite having a technology-free life before? - Quora

response.answer_text: Line of least resistance in many cases, I suspect. However, being accustomed to letter writing - as we were - the email phenomenon was something we embraced with enthusiasm. Our kids fixed us up with a basic PC, showed us which buttons to push and off we went! Most of us were accustomed to a typewriter so we just accepted the magic and continued to correspond as we always had. Then, our doting offspring introduced us to Facebook and we discovered the joy of instant chat. It was noticeable, apparently, that ‘younger viewers’ had long since gone on to greater things before cyber space became crowded out by ‘silver surfers’ exchanging pictures of the grandkids and complaints about poor quality sausages. Some were left behind at this point - my ex has never conquered the complexities of Facebook - and restricted themselves to the occasional email. We dropped like flies after that. The older we were, the more befuddled our brains became under that thinning white fuzz. We did, however, discover Google and the amazing realisation that we no longer had to plunge into obscure library books in order to gain information. It was all right there - at our finger tips! - if we could just conquer a tiny bit more technology. So many of us did just that! Fantastic development- well worth the effort! Beyond mastering the odd computer game, I don’t think I, personally, would have ventured much further after that … except that the old fashioned way of handling things like bill paying, bank accounts, council affairs were rapidly becoming obsolete! “You haven’t got a computer!?” became the new way of saying, “I think it’s time we popped you into a care home, dear!” Then … we got to 2020! Technology took on an entirely different meaning! It’s how we talk, face to face, with our families. It’s how we share experiences with friends. It’s how we do our shopping, attend yoga and painting classes, follow world events and watch baby foxes playing on someone else’s lawn! The old and bewildered finally realised technology wasn’t just a passing fad for the young - it was a vital communication tool for the world!

How are some older people heavily dependent on technology now despite having a technology-free life before? Virtually no one alive today has ever had a “technology-free life,” with the possible exception of “uncontacted peoples“ and people who live in communities that shun technology, like the Amish. Even people who were born in Third World countries a hundred years ago grew up with access to complex machinery powered by fossil fuels, commonly known as trains, planes, and automobiles, as well as things like telephones, radios, cameras, and semi-automatic weapons. When I tutored a friend of mine on the basics of electronics, I found myself using a book shelved in the open stacks at Shields Library, UC Davis. That book was published around the year 1900, and used plumbing diagrams to explain electronic circuits. Perhaps what the original poster is referring to is the fact that modern technology is often very different from technology that was around ten, twenty, or thirty years ago, and the reason that “older people” embrace that newer technology is because it is often much easier to use.  See: The Hydraulic Analogy for Electric Current Nowadays, I wouldn’t trust myself to change a flat tire, as my iPhone can now summon someone who changes a hundred flat tires a day for a fraction of the billable time I would lose. However, there was a time when I would change my own flat tires as well as my own engine oil, and replace worn out or broken car parts like the spark plugs, points, alternator, and water pump. I wouldn’t have the slightest idea how to do any of that anymore.

I just love the way-back machine! Janet, you are bright. You graduated in 1975? Do me a favor..please define old. Let’s see. Community Memory began in 1973, do you know Ward Christensen? You were around in 1978 when the snowstorm heralded the beginning of the BBS. Bulletin board system - Wikipedia Us ‘old people’ are actually a go-to. We are the precursors of current digital toys. I have spent my ‘careers’ in cooking and technology. I am also an artist and I make jewelry. Did you know that those combinations are a Meyer Briggs prediction? My mom is 93. She can run circles around a great many people technically but..I am here too. I remember 3 TV channels and the test screen at midnight. I remember learning that static and ‘snow’ was residual radioactivity. I also bake bread and I know the why of yeast. Did you know that yeast is in your own backyard? My grandmother made her own soap. Do you know how? Do you know how to get a sow to ‘not worry’ her piglets and feed them? Will you need to? That’s part of your answer. I provide answers that my mom is more than capable of getting herself. Who is making concerted use of technology? She is. She also has answers to questions that I will not ask. Btw, I graduated H/S in 1977. Come over and we’ll code, strip a desktop and troubleshoot a few issues. We are good, no? ❤️  **Disclaimer: I use bold face type because of Optic Neuritis, Multiple Sclerosis. It is for medical reasons. I suggest not leaving a comment If this bothers anyone**

By ncecessity. I live in an assisted living facility and can go out once twice a month. If I want to do anything other than watch TV and play bingo, I need to use technology. I use technology to provide me with a full life that I would not have otherwise. I keep in touch with friends on facebook, watch videos on YouTube and Netflix, listen to music on Spotify, order goods through instacart and Amazon, and perform meaningful activity on quora. I am on the cellphone 90% of the time.

When do you think older people grew up? Before the discovery of how to make fire? Older people did not grow up technology-free. They may not have had computers, but what do you think radios, gasoline engines, televisions, airplanes, ovens, satellites, electricity, moon landers, radar, etc… are? The technology older people used was different, not nonexistent. Besides, who do you think pioneered all the stuff you think of as technology? The technology that led to WiFi came into being in the 1940’s. The first programable computer dates from the 1930’s. The first electric programable computer dates from the 1940’s. The first digital computer was completed in 1946. To jump forward a bit, the first personal computer showed up in the 1970’s. Apple computers started in 1976 - not 2006. Don’t dismiss an older person just because they may be having a bit of trouble with the latest thing - for all you know, they helped lay the foundations for that latest thing to come into existence.

Probably because many things can no longer be done the old fashioned way. I am in my late 50’s, and can barely remember how we used to do many things. At first it was optional, then it slowly became a way of life, then it became mandatory. We still occasionally get a paper phone book, all business listings, which I throw out. I know a few people not much older than I am, who do not use the Internet, and they are at a great disadvantage.

From the UK perspective… Because the companies they’ve dealt with for perhaps decades - are now only dealing with people via email or text message ! Take me, for example… I’ll be 58 on the 27th of October - so I class myself as an ‘older’ person. Over the years since becoming self-dependent, I can remember a time when, (for example) if I had to call my electricity supplier, I would simply dial a local number. These days - not only is everything done online - you can bet the people dealing with your ‘problem’ aren’t even here in the UK ! Banks no longer issue paper statements unless you specifically ask for them (okay - that’s more of an environmental issue). Even requesting a taxi to get me home from the supermarket - they expect you to use an app to make the booking, instead of taking the details over the phone.

I can’t say for certain - it’s just my conjecture and part of that stems from a good friend that I have that owns every piece of conceivable tech crud invented. And, when it gets a year or so old - it’s out to replace it and get more new stuff! Reason being? It makes her feel ‘alive’, relevant and allows her to spend many hours a day perusing Twitter and all the rest and staying in touch with people as well as shopping online and just having a good time : )
